docs.lead_paragraph: Though the number of people working while retired has risen in 20 years, more people give up on the idea, largely because of the difficulty in finding a suitable job.
docs.abstract: Nearly three-fourths of Americans say they will continue working after retiring from their main job, but only 18.9 percent of Americans age 65 or older actually remain in the work force; one of the main reasons for the disconnect is that many people give up on the idea of working after retiring because of the difficulty of finding a suitable job.
docs.snippet: Though the number of people working while retired has risen in 20 years, more people give up on the idea, largely because of the difficulty in finding a suitable job.

docs.lead_paragraph: The deadline for people to sign up for health insurance won’t be extended, the secretary of health and human services said.

headline.main: Health Mandate Won’t Be Delayed, Sebelius Says
headline.print_headline: Health Mandate Won’t Be Delayed, Sebelius Says

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius testifies before the House Ways and Means Committee that the deadline for people to sign up for health insurance will not be extended and the requirement for most American to have coverage will not be delayed; declines to say whether the Obama administration is still committed to its original goal of enrolling seven million people in private coverage by March 31.
docs.snippet: The deadline for people to sign up for health insurance won’t be extended, the secretary of health and human services said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of nearly 200 Catholic employers filed a new lawsuit in Oklahoma against the federal government Wednesday, hoping to stop parts of the federal health care law that force them to provide insurance that covers contraceptives.

headline.print_headline: Catholic Group Mounts Challenge to Health Care Law

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. House Republicans said on Wednesday that they are pushing a plan to delay for five years the penalties for failing to buy health insurance under Obamacare, and to use the savings to spare doctors from a steep cut in Medicare payments.

headline.main: GOP Takes Aim at Obamacare to Fund Medicare
headline.print_headline: GOP Takes Aim at Obamacare to Fund Medicare

docs.snippet: U.S. House Republicans said on Wednesday that they are pushing a plan to delay for five years the penalties for failing to buy health insurance under Obamacare, and to use the savings to spare doctors from a steep cut in Medicare payments.

docs.lead_paragraph: There will be no delay in the penalty most Americans face under President Barack Obama's healthcare reform law if they fail to obtain health coverage this year, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Sebelius Says No Obamacare Mandate Delay, Enrollment Extension
headline.print_headline: Sebelius Says No Obamacare Mandate Delay, Enrollment Extension

docs.snippet: There will be no delay in the penalty most Americans face under President Barack Obama's healthcare reform law if they fail to obtain health coverage this year, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius said on Wednesday.
